data.title: Personal Search (1973)
data.meta_description: Basia and Krystyna are trying to smuggle clothes, perfumes and other things purchased abroad through the border back to Poland during communist period. They are accompanied by Basia's son Piotrek, infatuated with Krystyna. At the beginning everything appears to go smooth. Suddenly, however, the custom officer Roman stops pretending being fooled and demands body search which has to be carried out by next shift.
data.text:
A well-to-do woman, and what I presume are her daughter and son are smuggling clothes, food and beauty products in their Fiat from Italy back into Poland. They are stopped at the border and initially everything appears to be going well and then the titular intrusive act is demanded.

A weird one this, it flits between being dreamy and being gritty and is made even disparate by occasional TV adverts for the products they are trying to smuggle. I'd file it under odd but worth a poke.

Weird Frankenstein of a movie, combining commentary on Polish consumptionist tendencies in a vacuum of border control. However, the setting of the movie is ugly and unsettling but not in an interesting way.

The film tries to be hip and avangarde with editing advertisements into the movie but it comes off as very pretentious. As topping, let's add obnoxious music and annoying child actor giving a terrible performance.

The role of the child is annoying even in the script. Additionally it's also very questionable and uncomfortable, borderline pedophilic.

Also, Leszczy≈Ñski has an obsession with putting random naked women in his movies. And in this instance, the unnecessity of it is very jarring and aggresive.

Even Maklakiewicz and Mazurkiewcz cannot help the film with their somewhat solid performances.
